Conviction mo-caped physical performances look a little weird for the traditionally animated faces because they wanted to bring back Ironside for one last story. Ironside probably isn't physically able to do all the physical performances.
I don't mind that they switched out actors for iconic characters, if he performance is good. For instance, I thought Keifer Sutherland was better than David Hayter.

For myself, I have really liked to loved every multiplayer component in a halo game (first person shooter ones) , So for me, the really big indicator of a quality Halo game is the campaign as the deciding mark. For myself, I thought halo four was brilliant, and I hold it among my favorite video game stories ever made, which none of the other Halo games manage to do (even though I love the rest of the games). Halo fives storyline had some interesting moments and nice character bits here and there, but the overall narrative was just a mess, and they didn't really know what to do with bringing back Cortana. I don't think Brian Reed is a terrible writer, but I definitely think he shouldn't have been in charge of writing halo five. I hope they bring back Chris Schlerf for Halo 6.

I agree that you choose whatever gaming device you want, and don't be a jackass about it. Most modern platforms these days have a lot of variety and options to their games.
The only real problem I'd add with PC is spotty optimization. And if we're talking about Steam, we're also talking about one of the worst customer service a company has ever offered with a marketplace that's as unorganized and ugly as it is mired in asset-flips and rush-to-market crap games. I mean, I don't think SONY or Microsoft has great options for Indie devs, but at least there's a process for approval and people can RATE the damn things.
I also have a particular bee in my bonnet concerning PC and Piracy, but I won't get into that minefield.
I thought Halo 4 was incredible, and I really liked Halo 5. Gears of War 4 was also a great addition to the franchise.

The problem is the line between freedom of religious expression and forcing someone to go against their religious beliefs for the sake of another person is damn close to infringing on the Freedom of Religion. In the case of a judge however, they really should just preside within the law as they're not a business or something outside of the judicial system

A judge who can't separate their personal feelings from their duty to uphold the law should absolutely be removed from the bench.
But the problem is that many times in presiding over a case, their own interpretation of law and punishment with particular rulings comes down to personal interpretation on their part.

It's a damn good film. I think a lot of the hate is because it had the name "I, Robot" and except for some well-integrated references, it's not really the source material.
It's one of the better sci-fi films of the nought decade and still holds up. I LOVE how the movie plays with the unspoken "black-man-vs-white-man" mentality of trying to make Bruce Greenwood's corporate head as the bad guy. Everything from the design of everything, to the action (I adore how overpowering the NS5 robots actually are in combat), and it's an excellent character study of a man who burdens himself with self-hating guilt (Spooner).
I do wish it would get more love, especially that FANTASTIC [interrogation scene](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=05bGPiyM4jg)!

I think it's important to highlight (in the nicest way possible, of course) that senior management doesn't understand what your team does; it might be a good idea to present that.
I've never been the head of a team in the arena of business, so I have no experience here, but I wish you all the best.

im a massive fan of "this is 40" too.
I hated that movie. If you didn't know what the Hell "LOST" is, you'll have zero idea what the hell 40% of the jokes they attempt are about. I genuinely can't believe Paul Rudd's character is an adult and makes such a TERRIBLE business decision as a supposedly seasoned professional in his career when he has a family to look out for (not to mention that it's not a "new family", as he already has multiple kids and a long-term wife and he should know better than to gamble away his family's future for something he takes no research to understand, which I found completely idiotic despite the film's attempt to try and convince me that this is a reflection of real life). I also didn't see what the point was of Leslie Mann and Megan Fox off dancing in a club for no reason than to waste time and have MORE unnecessary celebrity cameos.
Like its done in a way where the jokes have literally no impact on the scenes, you can tell they changed things out as they used different jokes for the trailer then when they released. i dnno i feel just find it weird that you hate the man child archetype when thats literally what Deadpool is, he just also breaks the fourth wall, doesnt smoke weed and is a super hero
I disagree. Wade is shown to be uncaring to the world (and unlike most of Apatow's films, it's not trying to say that the world they live in is OUR world, especially with the stylistic sensibilities. A lot of the jokes are not interchangeable, especially in context to how they're used like with pre and post Deadpool transformation as the backbone to the character's sanity. Wade is a thug for hire, and only seems happy when he's with someone who shares his libido, style of humor, and quick wit. Scenes like the Zamboni death reveal, the cutting off the hand moment, the shock of Francis' escape, and so many other moments of visual comedy working in sync with Renolds acting and physical performances is just great (even BEFORE becoming Deadpool).
.. but then i accept that its a reddit meme'd movie that everyone goes out to bat for.
Much like you with "This is 40", I don't love Deadpool because of what other people said about it on Reddit. I love the movie because I love how the narrative is structured, how it smartly uses fourth wall breaking, makes the characters emotionally resonant by combining the drama and the humor flawlessly, has excellent action, utilizes every cast member so incredibly well, and quite frankly put so many movies in 2016 to shame in terms of how much care and effort went into everything which includes the editing and audio design and terrifically balancing the tone of the story.

Yes. I personally thought Funny People was a mess, and not just from the fragmented macro narrative. """""""jokes"""""" like making fun of that one German guys accent for an entire scene just strike me as disturbingly unfunny. Not to mention that the editing and cinematography is so pedestrian that I genuinely thought this was rushed to the theaters. The argument scene between Jonah Hill and Seth Rogen is one of the most terribly timed big-budget movie releases I can recall in YEARS.
I thought Knocked Up was just....awful. Once again, if you have zero understanding of the pop culture references they keep spouting out, you're lost. Not to mention we have a huge amount of shock value jokes (again, in dialog only) with the doorman scene or the "spelled coming wrong" moment.
Also, I'm just so incredibly god damn tired of the man-child archetype FOR EVERY FUCKING JUDD APATOW MOVIE! There isn't a single man in these films with one iota of understanding what the Hell responsibility or maturity is. Yeah, I can enjoy it every once in a while, but not every damn film!
Also, for Deadpool, that "Did I leave the stove on" moment (regardless of whether or not you thought it was funny, which I did) is supposed to blend together and cement Deadpool's mentality of not taking things seriously during incredibly dramatic moments while also breaking the artifice of the film and the fourth wall.
Look at how Tarantino does comedy in his films. He actually uses the film itself to accentuate and create a funny moment. Look at how he uses a zoom and a whoosing sound effect in Django Unchained to create humor after the sudden and dramatic death of [Calvin Candie](#spoiler). Here's the scene: [link](https://youtu.be/weKNVNSG-vk?t=22s)
I haven't even the slightest understanding from Apatow in terms of making a """""comedy""""" outside of people speaking dialog (and usually terrible dialog at that).
Not to mention this video that perfectly analyzes what Edgar Wright does so....uh....right, and what sooo many comedy film directors get wrong these days: [link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3FOzD4Sfgag)

I really didn't like No Country for Old Men. That third act non-ending completely spoiled the rest of the enjoyment I had for that film. I'd put Hot Fuzz and Eastern Promises into the "masterpiece" category, personally. 3:10 to Yuma is SO damn good.
Post-edit: I guess "screw me" for having a personal opinion on the matter.

It's British comedy, which is far, far superior (at least I think so).
If you're JUST comparing British comedy these days to most American comedies, I agree....mostly.
Deadpool, Tropic Thunder, The Nice Guys, Zombieland, Black Dynamite, Cabin in the Woods, Tucker and Dale vs. Evil, and Horrible Bosses are fantastic (not to mention a lot of great animated films from Pixar/Disney), and are among my favorite comedies ever made, but these days, Judd Apatow and his ilk during the naught decade and 2010s (in directing, writing, and producing) have replaced well made comedies with cheaply shat out snooze-fests that substitute making great jokes with the artifice of the medium for pop culture references with a shelf life of a piece of moldy bread, random celebrities cameos that are as distracting as they are unnecessary, and incessantly using shock value to generate an awkward laugh.
In my opinion, standards and competition for American blockbusters these days have never been higher, whereas American comedies are absolutely floundering, for the most part.
Anakin, my allegiance is to the Republic! To sand!!!

GRRM loves shades of grey, with the except of maybe Ramses. Dumbledore would not be completely good, and Voldemort would not be completely evil. Harry himself would probably be completely different.
That's one thing I do criticize against Martin. He claims that there really aren't good vs evil people in the world and Tolkien's "simplistic" view of morality, then has characters who are just wholly despicable people with no or very little redeeming value as characters, like Joffrey, Ramsey, Walder Frey, Cersei, etc. and have completely honorable good people like Jon, Ned, Brienne, Pod, Sam, etc. Tolkien ALSO had morally gray characters (moreso in the Jackson film adaptations) with characters like Boromir, Smeagul, Elrond, Denethor, Isildur, and Wormtongue.

What I really dig about this show is how much of a mystery David still is, especially in terms of whether or not he can be trusted (or even if he can trust himself). Having the perspective of him flip back and forth between sympathetic and dangerous makes for a fascinating dynamic.
Close-ups are "big budget Marvel"? I don't get that criticism, especially when close-ups are mostly used in this series for the OPPOSITE effect of how it's usually used in providing extreme discomfort even with characters we know and like. The romantic scenes (which don't always utilize music and warm lights, like when David is sleeping next to Syd) are the only ones that maintain consistent "normalcy" in the entire show. Everything else is underlined by the schizophrenic mentality of style reflecting David's mind. Following eye movement with shaky cam is evocative of the instability faced by characters in the show while showing them trying to maintain a small amount of mental stability.
I think the casting is good and I think the sound design is PHENOMENAL!
I haven't seen Gotham since the first season, but I much prefer this show. I really liked the actual "COP" portion of the show, but whenever they actually try to tie the show into future Batman villains or Bruce Wayne plot lines that won't pay off until he's an adult, it gets downright infuriating because they're all just winks, nods, and foreshadowing to things that won't be in the show in either the immediate or distant future of this series. Bruce Wayne does NOT need to be in Gotham, and often they cram him into episodes where he has absolutely no reason to be there.

* Daredevil * Cowboy Bebop * Trigun * Jericho * Prison Break * Band of Brothers * LOST * The Expanse * LOST * The West Wing * Twin Peaks * Samurai Jack * Legion * Riverdale * Firefly * Arrested Development * Clone High * The Young Pope * Deadwood * Profit

Samurai Jack is the equivalent of an average anime.
I would actually say it's more equivalent to Ozu, Mizogucchi, and Kurosawa in terms of cinematic sensibilities. It's more "traditional Japanese cinema" than most anime these days, even ones like Samurai Champloo, especially in terms of how much it lovingly focuses on environments and diagetic sounds.
The show is excellent, especially in the artistry of its visuals. I am SOOOOOOOOO deliriously happy the show is getting one last season to go out on.
I wouldn't call it average at all. It's surface-level "all ages" friendly content hide the amount of craftsmanship and care that makes it so damn brilliant.
The way that one questioning guy says "rRRRRRUUUUbies?!" on the boat always makes me laugh.
Is it still just episodic, or are they willing to go more with the Clone Wars route in having mini-arcs within a season?

Peter Parker from "The Spectacular Spider-man" - A normal guy trying to do right, make ends meet, make his family proud, has a good assortment of social issues with his friends and romantic interests in his life, and struggles with understanding what it means to a responsible person. That may not "count" since Peter Parker is from a comic book, but if James Bond can be considered a movie character even though he came from novels, than I thought it could count. I don't have any of his smarts or charm, but I do think I can really relate to his struggles as a regular joe just trying to keep his head on straight in a crazy chaotic world.

I like the show a lot (mostly in how well it uses the visual and auditory elements of screen-media), however it's still (for me) just "very good" that hasn't QUITE nudged over into "fully great" territory. Maybe it will be one of those shows that will need to be able to have the entire season behind it before showcasing me realizing how terrific it is (which has happened in the past). The trippy genre-and-style blending they do is great, but in terms of the narrative and characters, I haven't been given something to really chew on, like I could with Daredevil, The Wolverine, Captain America: Civil War, The Amazing Spider-man 2, Deadpool, X-men, Luke Cage, Doctor Strange, or a lot of other screen-media Marvel adaptations.
I won't deny that's it's absolutely BEAUTIFUL in terms of cinematography and editing, but I just need a little touch more in the characters and overall plot before I come down on the side of "YOU MUST WATCH THIS SHOW" immediately, like I feel with stuff that's on right now such as The Expanse, Mr. Robot, The Americans, or Riverdale (I know, the show surprised the Hell out of me).

If you just look at the show's overall plot, it might seem a bit underwhelming. However, I would argue that it's how the show is PRESENTED (sound design, editing, cinematography, composition, art design, etc.) in telling the story through visuals which gives it the appeal (which is the television/film's main appealing aspect of its medium.
It's a building mystery and fleshing the universe through bits and pieces seen through a fractured lens.
